datasets.title: Average Weekly Earnings
datasets.summary: Covering total pay, bonus pay and regular pay

datasets.title: Actual and usual weekly hours worked

statsBulletins.headline1: In April 2013 median gross weekly earnings for full-time employees were £517, up 2.2% from £506 in 2012.
statsBulletins.headline2: For men, full-time earnings were £556 per week, up 1.8%, compared with £459 for women, up 2.2%.
statsBulletins.headline3: The gender pay gap (i.e. the difference between men's and women's earnings as a percentage of men's earnings) based on median gross hourly earnings (excluding overtime) for full-time employees increased to 10.0% from 9.5% in 2012.
statsBulletins.title: Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings, 2013 Provisional Results
statsBulletins.summary: The Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE) is based on a 1% sample of employee jobs. This is drawn from HM Revenue and Customs Pay As You Earn (PAYE) records. This bulletin contains provisional results from the 2013 survey and revised results from the 2012 survey.

statsBulletins.headline1: Comparing the estimates for March to May 2014 with those for December 2013 to February 2014, employment continued to rise and unemployment continued to fall.
statsBulletins.headline2: There were 30.64 million people in work, 254,000 more than for December 2013 to February 2014 and 929,000 more than a year earlier.
statsBulletins.headline3: The proportion of people aged from 16 to 64 in work (the employment rate) continued to rise, reaching 73.1% for March to May 2014.
statsBulletins.title: UK Labour Market, July 2014
statsBulletins.summary: Labour market statistics (including employment, unemployment and economic inactivity) for the United Kingdom.

title: Earnings and working hours
summary: Earnings are the reward for work and they can be paid on a regular basis or as bonus pay. Total pay combines both regular and bonus pay. The Office for National Statistics reports the level and growth rate of average weekly total, regular and bonus pay. Working hours are given as the average weekly hours worked by full-time and part-time workers.

breadcrumb.title: Home
breadcrumb.summary: The UK's largest independent producer of official statistics and the recognised national statistical institute of the UK.

breadcrumb.title: Employment and Labour market
breadcrumb.summary: Labour market statistics tell us about people in and out of work. They cover a wide range of areas, such as: employment, unemployment, participation in the labour force, types of work, earnings, benefits, working patterns and workplace disputes.

breadcrumb.title: People in work
breadcrumb.summary: People in work are those classed as in employment. Figures here focus on employment rates, hours of work, full and part time workers and earnings.
